metadata.event_description: Detective puzzle 'The Chess Mystery' by Moe Zilla

story.full_text: It was almost magic. All the chess pieces looked like little people. My father had owned this set for over 20 years. All our lives, my father had fascinated my siblings and me as he moved the special pieces around the board. In a cabin in the woods, he stored the chess set safely for our family vacation each summer. Every year he'd play one game of chess against our uncle. And each year, the game always ended with Uncle Larry saying the same words. "Check mate." But this year would be surprisingly different, since there would be an interrupted game of chess -- and a mystery. After years of watching, my older brother Greg had decided to learn how to play chess. He'd carefully learned to move the pieces and then read several books about the winning strategies for chess. My sister and I didn't even know the names of the pieces, but Greg had practiced continuously against his friends until he was the best player in his school. This year when Uncle Larry arrived for the chess match, we'd finally see if he could beat a new challenger. "I hope Uncle Larry wins," said my younger sister Tina. "I like Uncle Larry!" Tina wasn't always a little angel -- but my father admitted that he was thinking about Uncle Larry, too. "He's always been proud of his chess-playing abilities -- though lately, I wonder if he's as sharp as he used to be. Sometimes he forgets things or repeats the same stories, and when he sends us a letter, the handwriting is really wobbly. It's okay if you beat him, but if you do -- remember to be a good sport!" But this afternoon, Greg seemed fearless. "I always win!" he shouted boastfully. "Uncle Larry will just have to get used to losing!" And as if on cue, we heard Uncle Larry pulling up in his car. The cabin was eight miles from the nearest town, so it was lucky we still had our father's chess set. Uncle Larry still remembered how to drive to the cabin, and he was happy to see us waiting for him. Greg wanted to start the game of chess as soon Larry arrived, but my mother and father had prepared a special dinner for the family. "Why don't you play the game of chess tomorrow night?" my father suggested. And that's how the mystery began. We'd talked and laughed after dinner, and Greg even set up the chess board in the living room, in anticipation of the big game that would happen the next day. My father carried in a big stack of logs to build a cozy fire, even though he had a back injury and wasn't supposed to lift anything more than 50 pounds. Getting ready for bed that night, I looked to see if my brother was worried. I tossed my sock at him, and said "Do you really think you can beat Uncle Larry?" He laughed as he pulled a pebble out of his shoe, and then threw it playfully across the room at me. "You'll see!" he said defensively. "You just wait until tomorrow." "I hope he beats you," Tina teased. "You'll all see," Greg said confidently. But the next morning -- all the chess pieces were gone. We couldn't play chess without the chess pieces, and we were too far away from the nearest town to get another set. To make things even more frustrating, the thief had left behind a taunting note! In neatly printed letters it said, "No chess game tonight" and instead of the word "night," the note had teasingly included a drawing of a knight -- the chess piece that looks like a horse. We thought Uncle Larry had hidden the pieces as a joke -- but we couldn't be sure, and Uncle Larry said playfully that he was "pretty sure" that he hadn't. Greg was furious. "I waited all year for this game!" Greg wailed melodramatically -- and he stormed outside to sulk in the woods. Our whole family felt bad, and the fun game of chess had turned into a real problem. "I'm going to try to solve this mystery!" I confided to my sister Tina. "Maybe dad's playing a joke on us," she suggested. "Maybe he didn't want to see Greg finally beat Uncle Larry after all of these years." "Or maybe Uncle Larry hid them himself," I suggested. "Though I hope that's not true." We began walking around the cabin, looking for clues. There was no sign of the missing chess set. And then Tina suggested that we look in the woods. There was nothing but trees and the sound of birds chirping. Then suddenly, Tina grabbed my arm and pointed towards the ground by a tree. "Look!" she said. I didn't see anything at first -- just the hiking trail, some shrubby bushes, and the tree roots. But then I noticed something white and shiny. It was a chess piece -- a white knight! And it was lying on its side in a pile of pine needles. "That's ONE piece," Tina said optimistically. "Now we just need to find the rest." We searched for clues around the tree but found disappointingly few. The hiking trail was too firm to pick up footprints, and the dirt around the tree was filled with little rocks. I studied the bark of the tree, while Tina ran up ahead on the trail. But I noticed something up in the tree that didn't look right. It wasn't wood -- it was a black plastic garbage bag. It was at least 20 feet above the trail, wedged against the tree's trunk where it was joined by a thick branch. There was a hole in the bottom where another white chess piece was poking through. As we stared curiously, a strange thing happened. The white king fell to the trail. Then as a breeze blew threw the braches, the bag came tumbling down. It spilled a pile of chess pieces across the trail, a messy jumble of curvy little pawns and mysterious bishops. "The chess pieces!" Tina squealed. We scooped up all the pieces, and ran back into the house. My father laughed and said "Nice work!" and Uncle Larry asked, "Where were they?” Greg was still sulking mood, and seemed disappointed that he hadn't found the pieces himself. Tina glowed with pride, so happy that she'd saved the day. For a minute I wondered if she'd hidden the pieces herself -- just so she could be the one to find them! As the laughter died down, there was a strange silence over our family. "Shall we set up the chess game?" my father finally asked. "After all this excitement, it'll be the best game ever." "Maybe we shouldn't," I said with concern. "There's obviously someone in this family who wants to stop this game from being played -- and they want that badly enough to steal all of our chess pieces." "Maybe this can be the game that never was," my mother suggested gently. My parents weren't sure what to do. To help them out, I decided to make a dramatic announcement. I said "I know who stole the chess pieces."

detection.solution:
<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1. Motive  
   •  Uncle Larry – wants to avoid being beaten, but he is elderly, forgetful and proud; a childish joke does not fit his personality.  
   •  Father – wants to spare Uncle Larry’s feelings, but he is very fond of the set and has a bad back; climbing a tree with a bag of pieces is the last thing he would do.  
   •  Mother – no reason is ever suggested.  
   •  Tina – openly says she hopes Uncle Larry wins, but she (and the narrator) “don’t even know the names of the pieces,” so the word-play note using a KNIGHT seems beyond her.  
   •  Greg – boasts that he “always wins,” but the only person he has ever played is schoolmates.  If he loses publicly to Uncle Larry his pride will suffer.  He therefore has a real motive to be sure the game is never played.

2. Opportunity  
   •  The theft had to occur late that night after the board was left ready in the living-room.  
   •  Only someone who was still awake and mobile inside the cabin could do it without being seen.  
   •  The narrator and Greg share a room; while talking before sleeping the narrator notices Greg still wearing his shoes and picking a pebble out of one of them – proof he had been outside after the rest of the family had settled in.  
   •  A 20-foot climb up a tree requires a young, fit person.  Greg (a strong teenager) can do it.  His father (bad back), Uncle Larry (elderly) and his mother (no hint she ever climbs trees) are improbable climbers.  Tina is light enough, but again she lacks the chess knowledge shown in the note.

3. Physical evidence   
   •  Pebble in Greg’s shoe → he was outdoors at night.  
   •  Note printed neatly with a picture of a KNIGHT substituting for “night.”  The author must know the piece is a knight and must enjoy chess puns – exactly Greg, the family’s new chess enthusiast.  
   •  The single white knight lying on the path is the very piece drawn in the note – a theatrical touch a show-off like Greg would add.  
   •  The garbage bag was forced into a fork of the tree: someone tall enough to reach the first branches and strong enough to lift the bag up while climbing.

4. Logical deduction  
   •  Only Greg had (a) a strong motive, (b) the physical ability, (c) evidence of being outdoors, and (d) the chess knowledge displayed in the teasing note.  
   •  All other family members lack at least one of those essential elements.  Therefore Greg is the thief.
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Greg (older brother), Tina (younger sister), Father, Mother, Uncle Larry
</SUSPECTS>

<CULPRIT>
Greg
</CULPRIT>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
After dinner Greg began to worry that, despite all his studying, he might lose to Uncle Larry and damage his newly won reputation as “the best player in school.”  
Late that night, when the rest of the family was preparing for bed, he slipped back into the living-room, swept all 32 chess pieces into a plastic garbage bag, folded up a sheet of paper on which he had already printed the taunting words “NO CHESS GAME TO-⁠” and drew a picture of a KNIGHT in place of “night.”  
Wearing his shoes, he crept outside, walked along the hiking trail, climbed about twenty feet up a sturdy tree and jammed the garbage bag into the fork between trunk and branch.  Intentionally or not, a small hole in the bag allowed the white knight to fall out, creating the perfect dramatic clue.  A pebble lodged in his shoe during the climb.  
Next morning, he feigned outrage and stormed off into the woods to complete the role of innocent victim.  The plan very nearly worked, but the fallen knight led his little sister and the narrator to the tree, the wind shook the bag loose, and the truth could be pieced together from the clues he had inadvertently left.
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
•  Father – He loves the set, has a bad back and should not climb.  Carrying logs is painful enough; scrambling twenty feet up a tree with a bag is unrealistic.  
•  Mother – No motive is ever suggested, and nothing places her near the scene.  
•  Uncle Larry – Elderly, unsteady handwriting, probably incapable of climbing a tall tree at night, and he arrived only hours earlier.  
•  Tina – Although she wishes Uncle Larry well and is agile enough to climb, she is on record as not knowing the chess pieces’ names; the sophisticated “knight/night” pun and the neat block lettering do not match her abilities.  She was also genuinely delighted to recover the pieces, behaviour inconsistent with someone whose goal was to prevent the game.
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>

original_metadata.reveal_text:
"Did Dad steal the pieces?" Tina asked.
"He couldn't have!" I pointed out. "With his bad back, Dad couldn't pull his whole body weight all the way up that tree. The pieces were at least 20 feet off the ground!"
"I bet Tina stole the pieces," Greg said. "She's been rooting for Uncle Larry all along."
"But Tina doesn't even know the names of the pieces," I pointed out. "So it wouldn't be her who was drawing a picture of a knight to stand for 'night'."
"Uncle Larry knows the name of the pieces," my mother suggested, a little worried.
"But his handwriting is wobbly," I reminded her. "We'd be able to recognize the handwriting if Uncle Larry had written the note."
My father looked around the room, and his eyes fell on the only remaining suspect.
Looking embarrassed and ashamed, Greg looked like he was about to cry.
"Uncle Larry's so good," he said. "I didn't think I could beat him."
I felt bad for Greg, and we stood in stunned silence until my father finally taught him a lesson. "Being a good sport means being brave and playing the game -- whether or not you win or lose." We set up the chess pieces, and reminded Greg that he'd beaten everybody in his school -- and finally the great chess match happened after all.
And Uncle Larry beat Greg in 10 minutes.
